p: Quinoa ( Chenopodium quinoa Willd.) is a pseudocereal crop with high nutritional value [ 1, 2]. Quinoa varieties are classified as bitter or sweet depending upon saponin content of the seed. Although saponins in quinoa are highly accumulated in the seed pericarp, they are also present in lower concentrations in leaves. Saponin biosynthesis in quinoa is regulated by the triterpene saponin biosynthesis activating regulator-like1 (TSARL1) gene [ 3– 5]. Mechanical abrasion or water rinsing is typically used to remove saponin from the seed of bitter varieties [ 6, 7]. Because these methods are costly and reduce nutritional value of the seeds [ 6, 8], quinoa cultivars with low seed saponin content (sweet cultivars) are desired [ 9]. Saponins from quinoa are active against several plant pathogens including viruses and are pre-existing defense factors in other pathosystems [ 10– 14].
